{{Discrimination sidebar|state=collapsed}} '''Structural discrimination''' is an unintentional form of [[discrimination]] resulting from policies that were enacted with the intent to be neutral with regard to characteristics such as race and gender.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lee|first1=S|last2=Chiu|first2=MY|last3=Tsang|first3=A|last4=Chui|first4=H|last5=Kleinman|first5=A|title=Stigmatizing experience and structural discrimination associated with the treatment of schizophrenia in Hong Kong.|journal=Social Science & Medicine (1982)|date=April 2006|volume=62|issue=7|pages=1685-96|pmid=16174547}}</ref>{{rp|1693}}<ref name=pincus/> Such discrimination occurs when these policies, despite apparently being neutral, nevertheless have disproportionately negative effects on certain societal groups.<ref name=pincus>{{cite journal|last1=PINCUS|first1=F. L.|title=Discrimination Comes in Many Forms: Individual, Institutional, and Structural|journal=American Behavioral Scientist|date=1 November 1996|volume=40|issue=2|pages=186â€“194|doi=10.1177/0002764296040002009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |url=https://www.nap.edu/read/10887/chapter/7#63 |title=Measuring Racial Discrimination |publisher=National Academy of Sciences |year=2004 |editor-last=Blank |editor-first=Rebecca M. |page=63}}</ref> Some conceptualizations of structural discrimination focus on past forms of discrimination that have resulted in present-day inequality, while others focus on policies that still exist today and can have disproportionately negative effects on minority groups.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pager|first1=D|last2=Shepherd|first2=H|title=The Sociology of Discrimination: Racial Discrimination in Employment, Housing, Credit, and Consumer Markets.|journal=Annual Review of Sociology|date=1 January 2008|volume=34|pages=181-209|pmid=20689680|pmc=2915460}}</ref> ==See also== *[[Structural discrimination in New Zealand]] ==References== {{Reflist}}
